melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

text: ਕੜਛੀਆ ਫਿਰੰਨ੍ਹਿ ਸੁਆਉ ਨ ਜਾਣਨ੍ਹਿ ਸੁਞੀਆ ॥

translation.text: The ladles cruise through the food, but they do not know the taste of it.

transliteration.text: karashīā phirannh suāu n jānanh suñīā .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev
author.description:
Guru Arjan Dev [1563 - 1606] was the fifth Guru of the Sikhs, born at Goindval. He was the youngest of the three sons of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.

text: ਸੇਈ ਮੁਖ ਦਿਸੰਨ੍ਹਿ ਨਾਨਕ ਰਤੇ ਪ੍ਰੇਮ ਰਸਿ ॥੧॥

translation.text: I long to see the faces of those, O Nanak, who are imbued with the essence of the Lord's Love. ||1||

transliteration.text: sēī mukh disannh nānak ratē prēm ras .1.

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

translation.text: Through the Tracker, I discovered the tracks of those who ruined my crops.

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. text: ਤੈ ਸਹਿ ਦਿਤੀ ਵਾੜਿ ਨਾਨਕ ਖੇਤੁ ਨ ਛਿਜਈ ॥੨॥

translation.text: You, O Lord, have put up the fence; O Nanak, my fields shall not be plundered again. ||2||

transliteration.text: tai sah ditī vār nānak khēt n shijaī .2.

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

text: ਆਰਾਧਿਹੁ ਸਚਾ ਸੋਇ ਸਭੁ ਕਿਛੁ ਜਿਸੁ ਪਾਸਿ ॥

translation.text: Worship in adoration that True Lord; everything is under His Power.

transliteration.text: ārādhih sachā sōi sabh kish jis pās .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

author.author: Guru Arjan Dev
author.description:
Guru Arjan Dev [1563 - 1606] was the fifth Guru of the Sikhs, born at Goindval. He was the youngest of the three sons of Guru Ram Das, the fourth Sikh Guru.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.

text: ਦੁਹਾ ਸਿਰਿਆ ਖਸਮੁ ਆਪਿ ਖਿਨ ਮਹਿ ਕਰੇ ਰਾਸਿ ॥

translation.text: He Himself is the Master of both ends; in an instant, He adjusts our affairs.

transliteration.text: duhā siriā khasam āp khin mah karē rās .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

Guru Arjan Dev finished the construction of the Harimandir Sahib, the Golden Temple, and compiled the first Sikh scripture, known as the Adi Granth. Shortly after he became the first martyr of the Sikh religion, which formed a turning point in the development of the faith.

text: ਤਿਆਗਹੁ ਸਗਲ ਉਪਾਵ ਤਿਸ ਕੀ ਓਟ ਗਹੁ ॥

translation.text: Renounce all your efforts, and hold fast to His Support.

transliteration.text: tiāgah sagal upāv tis kī ōt gah .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

text: ਪਉ ਸਰਣਾਈ ਭਜਿ ਸੁਖੀ ਹੂੰ ਸੁਖ ਲਹੁ ॥

translation.text: Run to His Sanctuary, and you shall obtain the comfort of all comforts.

transliteration.text: pau saranāī bhaj sukhī hūn sukh lah .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

text: ਕਰਮ ਧਰਮ ਤਤੁ ਗਿਆਨੁ ਸੰਤਾ ਸੰਗੁ ਹੋਇ ॥

translation.text: The karma of good deeds, the righteousness of Dharma and the essence of spiritual wisdom are obtained in the Society of the Saints.

transliteration.text: karam dharam tat giān santā sang hōi .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. However, it is only when the water begins to slowly seep through their joined hands that the person comes to realise the real value and importance of the water. Similarly Raag Gujari leads the listener to realise and become aware of passing time and in this way comes to value the precious nature of time itself. The revelation brings the listener to an awareness and admission of their own death and mortality, making them utilise their remaining ‘life time’ more wisely.

text: ਜਪੀਐ ਅੰਮ੍ਰਿਤ ਨਾਮੁ ਬਿਘਨੁ ਨ ਲਗੈ ਕੋਇ ॥

translation.text: Chanting the Ambrosial Nectar of the Naam, no obstacle shall block your way.

transliteration.text: japīai anmrit nām bighan n lagai kōi .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. text: ਜਿਸ ਨੋ ਆਪਿ ਦਇਆਲੁ ਤਿਸੁ ਮਨਿ ਵੁਠਿਆ ॥

translation.text: The Lord abides in the mind of one who is blessed by His Kindness.

transliteration.text: jis nō āp daiāl tis man vuthiā .

melody.description: If there is a perfect simile for Raag Gujari, it would be that of a person isolated in the desert, who has their hands cupped, holding water. translation.text: All treasures are obtained, when the Lord and Master is pleased. ||12||
